questions.question: Fill in each blank with the word most or least. (a) A function F is one-to-one if, and only if, each element in the co-domain of F is the image of at ___ one element in the domain of F. (b) A function F is onto if, and only if, each element in the co-domain of F is the image of at ___ one element in the domain of F.

When asked to state the definition of one-to-one, a student replies, 'A function f is one-to-one if, and only if, every element of X is sent by f to exactly one element of Y.' Give a counterexample to show that the student's reply is incorrect.

questions.question: Let X = {1, 5, 9} and Y = {3, 4, 7}. Define f : X ‚Üí Y by f(1) = 4, f(5) = 7, f(9) = 4, and g : X ‚Üí Y by g(1) = 7, g(5) = 3, g(9) = 4. For each function determine if it is one-to-one and/or onto.

function_f.explanation: Not one-to-one because f(1) = f(9) = 4. Not onto because 3 in Y has no pre-image in X.

function_g.explanation: One-to-one because each element maps to unique value. Onto because every element in Y (7,3,4) is mapped to by some element in X.

questions.question: Let X = {a, b, c, d} and Y = {e, f, g}. Given arrow diagrams for functions F and G, determine if each is one-to-one and/or onto.

function_F.explanation: Not one-to-one because elements c and d map to same element e. Onto because each element in Y has a pre-image in X.

function_G.explanation: Not one-to-one due to multiple elements mapping to same value. Not onto because element g has no pre-image.

questions.question: Let X = {a, b, c} and Y = {w, x, y, z}. Given arrow diagrams for functions H and K, determine if each is one-to-one and/or onto.

function_H.explanation: Not one-to-one because b and c map to y. Not onto because z has no pre-image.

function_K.explanation: One-to-one because each element maps to distinct element. Not onto because z has no pre-image.

questions.question: Let X = {1, 2, 3}, Y = {1, 2, 3, 4}, and Z = {1, 2}. Define: (a) A one-to-one but not onto function f:X‚ÜíY (b) An onto but not one-to-one function g:X‚ÜíZ (c) A function h:X‚ÜíX neither one-to-one nor onto (d) A one-to-one and onto function k:X‚ÜíX that is not the identity function

a.explanation: One-to-one because each maps to distinct element, not onto because 1 has no pre-image

b.explanation: Onto because all elements in Z have pre-images, not one-to-one because g(1) = g(2)

c.explanation: Neither one-to-one (multiple elements map to 2) nor onto (1 and 3 have no pre-images)

d.explanation: One-to-one and onto because each element has unique mapping, not identity because elements don't map to themselves

questions.question: Determine if f(x) = (x + 1)/x, for all real numbers x ‚â† 0 is one-to-one. Justify your answer.
